lexUnit.name: inclined.a
lexUnit.definition: COD: have a specified tendency, disposition, or talent.

sentence.text: They will be less inclined to be loyal to Delhi .
But they were less inclined to tolerate this kind of thing than they used to be .
Older children were less inclined to wait for attention than younger children .
Consequently , subscribers to the Austrian tradition would be somewhat less inclined to an actively pro-interventionist stance .
Other excitements took their place but I was more inclined to stare at them in amazement than paint them .
Yet the more she thought about it , the more she was inclined to let him have his way .
Now if they could just do the same to the beers themselves , and improve the taste , more people might be inclined to drink them .
This age group were more inclined to blame unemployment and housing conditions for the decline .

Van Gogh 's life has so often been made the subject of literary treatment that the art historian is strongly inclined to leave the biographical matter severely alone and concentrate exclusively on the artistic aspect .
And when I find that I 'm strongly inclined to suppose that Shakespeare has put it there .
Arthur is inclined to be delicate and it 's feared he has not long to live .
According to his pupil , Norman Swindin [ q.v. ] , he was inclined to be irascible at times but had a dry sense of humour and the ability to recognize and laugh at his own mistakes .
They were inclined to work with him , but had yet to commit themselves fully .
In the Pre-Campaign Wave and the two Campaign Waves we asked electors to give each party a mark out of ten for how inclined they were to vote for it .
I am inclined to be witty .
" After five days of bad food and bad stomach , the king was not inclined to be suspicious of someone who said that Prince Rainbow had sent him to make him better .
No wonder he was inclined to be defensive .
Aggressively inclined courtiers like Prince Menshikov ( who was much more militant as a diplomat and as Navy Minister than as Governor of Finland ) were beginning to press for pre-emptive action .
There was no doubt that Joanna was inclined to be rather blunt , but , reminding herself that they were equal partners , she said cheerfully , ` Go on in , look around and do your stuff .
If the House of Commons is not inclined to accept the Lords amendments , something has to give if the Bill is not to fail .
Anyone inclined to question the advisability of monogamy should read of the troubles of Jacob , David and others who took more than one wife .
Several leading nobles by this truce lost control of , and revenues from , estates which they had possessed in Scotland : they were naturally inclined to emphasize its temporary nature .
My mother looked annoyed and inclined to dispute this but , naturally , she could n't .
` The shops here are very good , but Dana is inclined to turn her nose up at anything outside London or Paris , so I imagine an hour could see her back at the flat . "
As anthropologists we are inclined to accept the citizen 's point of view and to neglect the bureaucrat 's version .
I AM inclined to agree with Alan Shearer .
He exhorted members to work against the ` offensive and untrue " beliefs that agencies are inclined to rip off clients , stressing the IPA 's commitment to ` weed out dubious practice " .
She seemed inclined to give Harry short shrift , but at his mention of Heather 's name , she relented and showed him into the front room , where a meagre measure of calm and quiet prevailed .
When the telephone rang yet again , she was inclined not to answer it .
The Shiite-generated Amal and Hezbollah , underpinned by Syria and Iran respectively , were inclined to sometimes violent disagreement with one another .
